segment.source: The Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern
segment.target: The Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern

segment.source: The Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern is common in a lot of XAML apps.
segment.target: The Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern is common in a lot of XAML apps.

segment.source: (MVVM is very similar to Fowler’s description of the Model-View-Presenter pattern, but it is tailored to XAML).
segment.target: (MVVM is very similar to Fowler’s description of the Model-View-Presenter pattern, but it is tailored to XAML).

segment.source: The issue with the MVVM pattern is that it can inadvertently lead to apps that have too many layers and too many allocations.
segment.target: The issue with the MVVM pattern is that it can inadvertently lead to apps that have too many layers and too many allocations.

segment.source: The motivations for MVVM are these.
segment.target: The motivations for MVVM are these.

segment.source: Separation of concerns.
segment.target: Separation of concerns.

segment.source: It’s always helpful to divide a problem into smaller pieces, and a pattern like MVVM or MVC is a way to divide an app (or even a single control) into smaller pieces: the actual view, a logical model of the view (view-model), and the view-independent app logic (the model).
segment.target: It’s always helpful to divide a problem into smaller pieces, and a pattern like MVVM or MVC is a way to divide an app (or even a single control) into smaller pieces: the actual view, a logical model of the view (view-model), and the view-independent app logic (the model).

segment.source: In particular, it’s a popular workflow to have designers own the view using one tool, developers own the model using another tool, and design integrators own the view-model using both tools.
segment.target: In particular, it’s a popular workflow to have designers own the view using one tool, developers own the model using another tool, and design integrators own the view-model using both tools.

segment.source: Unit testing.
segment.target: Unit testing.

segment.source: You can unit test the view-model (and consequently the model) independent of the view, thereby not relying on creating windows, driving input, and so on.
segment.target: You can unit test the view-model (and consequently the model) independent of the view, thereby not relying on creating windows, driving input, and so on.

segment.source: By keeping the view small, you can test a large portion of your app without ever having to create a window.
segment.target: By keeping the view small, you can test a large portion of your app without ever having to create a window.

segment.source: Agility to user experience changes.
segment.target: Agility to user experience changes.

segment.source: The view tends to see the most frequent changes, and the most late changes, as the user experience is tweaked based on end-user feedback.
segment.target: The view tends to see the most frequent changes, and the most late changes, as the user experience is tweaked based on end-user feedback.

segment.source: By keeping the view separate, these changes can be accommodated more quickly and with less churn to the app.
segment.target: By keeping the view separate, these changes can be accommodated more quickly and with less churn to the app.

segment.source: There are multiple concrete definitions of the MVVM pattern, and 3rd party frameworks that help implement it.
segment.target: There are multiple concrete definitions of the MVVM pattern, and 3rd party frameworks that help implement it.

segment.source: But strict adherence to any variation of the pattern can lead to apps with a lot more overhead than can be justified.
segment.target: But strict adherence to any variation of the pattern can lead to apps with a lot more overhead than can be justified.

segment.source: XAML data binding (the {Binding} markup extension) was designed in part to enable model/view patterns.
segment.target: XAML data binding (the {Binding} markup extension) was designed in part to enable model/view patterns.

segment.source: But {Binding} brings with it non-trivial working set and CPU overhead.
segment.target: But {Binding} brings with it non-trivial working set and CPU overhead.

segment.source: Creating a {Binding} causes a series of allocations, and updating a binding target can cause reflection and boxing.
segment.target: Creating a {Binding} causes a series of allocations, and updating a binding target can cause reflection and boxing.

segment.source: These problems are being addressed with the {x:Bind} markup extension, which compiles the bindings at build time.
segment.target: These problems are being addressed with the {x:Bind} markup extension, which compiles the bindings at build time.

segment.source: Recommendation: use {x:Bind}.
segment.target: Recommendation: use {x:Bind}.

segment.source: It’s popular in MVVM to connect Button.Click to the view-model using an ICommand, such as the common DelegateCommand or RelayCommand helpers.
segment.target: It’s popular in MVVM to connect Button.Click to the view-model using an ICommand, such as the common DelegateCommand or RelayCommand helpers.

segment.source: Those commands are extra allocations, though, including the CanExecuteChanged event listener, adding to the working set, and adding to the startup/navigation time for the page.
segment.target: Those commands are extra allocations, though, including the CanExecuteChanged event listener, adding to the working set, and adding to the startup/navigation time for the page.

segment.source: Recommendation: As an alternative to using the convenient ICommand interface, consider putting event handlers in your code-behind and attaching them to the view events and call a command on your view-model when those events are raised.
segment.target: Recommendation: As an alternative to using the convenient ICommand interface, consider putting event handlers in your code-behind and attaching them to the view events and call a command on your view-model when those events are raised.

segment.source: You'll also need to add extra code to disable the Button when the command is unavailable.
segment.target: You'll also need to add extra code to disable the Button when the command is unavailable.

segment.source: It’s popular in MVVM to create a Page with all possible configurations of the UI, then collapse parts of the tree by binding the Visibility property to properties in the VM.
segment.target: It’s popular in MVVM to create a Page with all possible configurations of the UI, then collapse parts of the tree by binding the Visibility property to properties in the VM.

segment.source: This adds unnecessarily to startup time and possibly to working set (because some parts of the tree may never become visible).
segment.target: This adds unnecessarily to startup time and possibly to working set (because some parts of the tree may never become visible).

segment.source: Recommendations: Use the x:DeferLoadStrategy feature to defer unnecessary portions of the tree out of startup.
segment.target: Recommendations: Use the x:DeferLoadStrategy feature to defer unnecessary portions of the tree out of startup.

segment.source: Also, create separate user controls for the different modes of the page and use code-behind to keep only the necessary controls loaded.
segment.target: Also, create separate user controls for the different modes of the page and use code-behind to keep only the necessary controls loaded.

segment.source: C++/CX recommendations
segment.target: C++/CX recommendations

segment.source: Use the latest version.
segment.target: Use the latest version.

segment.source: There are continual performance improvements made to the C++/CX compiler.
segment.target: There are continual performance improvements made to the C++/CX compiler.

segment.source: Ensure your app is building using the latest toolset.
segment.target: Ensure your app is building using the latest toolset.

segment.source: Disable RTTI (/GR-).
segment.target: Disable RTTI (/GR-).

segment.source: RTTI is on by default in the compiler so, unless your build environment switches it off, you’re probably using it.
segment.target: RTTI is on by default in the compiler so, unless your build environment switches it off, you’re probably using it.

segment.source: RTTI has significant overhead, and unless your code has a deep dependency on it, you should turn it off.
segment.target: RTTI has significant overhead, and unless your code has a deep dependency on it, you should turn it off.

segment.source: The XAML framework has no requirement that your code use RTTI.
segment.target: The XAML framework has no requirement that your code use RTTI.

segment.source: Avoid heavy use of ppltasks.
segment.target: Avoid heavy use of ppltasks.

segment.source: Ppltasks are very convenient when calling async WinRT APIs, but they come with significant code size overhead.
segment.target: Ppltasks are very convenient when calling async WinRT APIs, but they come with significant code size overhead.

segment.source: The C++/CX team is working on a language feature – await – that will provide much better performance.
segment.target: The C++/CX team is working on a language feature – await – that will provide much better performance.

segment.source: In the meantime, balance your use of ppltasks in the hot paths of your code.
segment.target: In the meantime, balance your use of ppltasks in the hot paths of your code.

segment.source: Avoid use of C++/CX in the “business logic” of your app.
segment.target: Avoid use of C++/CX in the “business logic” of your app.

segment.source: C++/CX is designed to be a convenient way to access WinRT APIs from C++ apps.
segment.target: C++/CX is designed to be a convenient way to access WinRT APIs from C++ apps.

segment.source: It makes use of wrappers that have overhead.
segment.target: It makes use of wrappers that have overhead.

segment.source: You should avoid C++/CX inside the business logic/model of your class, and reserve it for use at the boundaries between your code and WinRT.
segment.target: You should avoid C++/CX inside the business logic/model of your class, and reserve it for use at the boundaries between your code and WinRT.
